Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Susanne Striegler of the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville studies selected glyconoamidines as putative transition state analogs of glycoside hydrolysis reactions, evaluates copper(II) complexes as catalysts for glycoside hydrolysis in alkaline solution and investigates microgels catalysts derived from inverse miniemulsions. The research encompasses synthesis, spectroscopic evaluation, molecular recognition and material science and provides training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

The proposed catalysts are of outstanding scientific and industrial interest and are expected to provide a novel platform for a shortened synthesis of glycoconjugates and biomarkers of potential pharmacological importance as a long term goal. Further broader impacts on society include outreach efforts of the team to local high and middle schools, and the development of new classroom teaching styles to facilitate student retention, increase graduate rate, and decrease costs and preparation time until graduation.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
As a result of this project (CHE-1305543), a library of 25 new sugar-related drugs is available, chemically characterized, and evaluated with biochemical and spectroscopic techniques. All compounds were characterized as potent inhibitors of sugar-transforming enzymes from fungal, bacterial and mammal sources that act in concentrations as low as nanomolar. This result places many compounds of the library among the most potent inhibitors of glycosidases known today.

Furthermore, chiral binuclear Cu(II) complexes were synthesized, characterized in the solid state, and evaluated as catalysts that break dummy compounds with sugar bonds. The result classifies the new compounds as potent catalysts that discriminate sugars at physiological pH values. The work has been protected by a patent application and reflects the uniqueness and potential of the developed catalysts. Further preliminary data disclose applicability of the catalysts to hydrolyze natural saccharides, such as milk sugar, table sugar and other saccharides and may open new directions for the use of biorenewable resources. Investigations on microgel catalysts were limited due to significant budget cuts.

 

Over the past years, the project provided training opportunities for 5 postdoctoral researchers, 3 graduate students, 1 research associate, 19 undergraduate students, 1 REU student, 2 high school students, and 3 middle school students. Of those 34 research trainees involved in this project up to date, 19 qualify as minority (i.e. 3 African-American, 1 Native Indian, and 15 females (1 postdoc, 2 graduate students, 10 undergraduate students, 1 high school student)). Outreach to middle- and home-schooled students was additionally provided and resulted in a lot of fun.

 

Results from this project were disclosed in 8 peer-reviewed publications, 9 theses, and one provisional patent application. Research outcomes were disseminated at international, national and regional conferences in 2 invited seminars, 30+ poster presentations, and 4 departmental seminars.


Last Modified: 11/12/2017
Modified by: Susanne Striegler
